title: [BUGFIX] Fixing nuclei density fields.

content.raw: is this an enzo-specific thing? or should other codes that have nuclear species follow suit?
content.html: is this an enzo-specific thing? or should other codes that have nuclear species follow suit?

content.raw: Enzo might be the only frontend set up for it right now, but it is designed for use with any code following chemistry species fields.  The only thing that needs to happen to enable it  is to create the list of known species names.  You can see this done in ``setup_species_fields`` in ``yt/frontends/enzo/fields.py``.
content.html: Enzo might be the only frontend set up for it right now, but it is designed for use with any code following chemistry species fields. The only thing that needs to happen to enable it is to create the list of known species names. You can see this done in setup_species_fields in yt/frontends/enzo/fields.py.

content.raw: Ah, since it said nuclei, I thought this was for nuclear species, but here you say chemistry species, so are we treating these as distinct in yt?  We deal with nuclear species in our codes.
content.html: Ah, since it said nuclei, I thought this was for nuclear species, but here you say chemistry species, so are we treating these as distinct in yt? We deal with nuclear species in our codes.

content.raw: Here I am defining nuclei density to be the sum of number densities from all species of an element.  If there is a better name for that, I'm fine with changing to avoid collisions.
content.html: Here I am defining nuclei density to be the sum of number densities from all species of an element. If there is a better name for that, I'm fine with changing to avoid collisions.

content.raw:
Would 'number density' be sufficient?  Mike's comment is that in our work -
supernovae and other white dwarf/neutron star-related simulations - nuclei
mean the actual nucleus of the isotopes, including neutron and proton.
Electrons are separate, in terms of the contribution to the EOS.
content.html: Would 'number density' be sufficient? Mike's comment is that in our work - supernovae and other white dwarf/neutron star-related simulations - nuclei mean the actual nucleus of the isotopes, including neutron and proton. Electrons are separate, in terms of the contribution to the EOS.

content.raw:
Two things -- I can see why this is degenerate, particularly with PyNE data
being supported now.  The other thing is that in the field naming YTEP we
discuss some of the different names, and we should update that once we're
done.

Ideas for what Britton's trying to get across:

 * all_H_density
 * H_Z_density

maybe others?
content.html:
Two things -- I can see why this is degenerate, particularly with PyNE data being supported now. The other thing is that in the field naming YTEP we discuss some of the different names, and we should update that once we're done.

Ideas for what Britton's trying to get across:

  • all_H_density
  • H_Z_density

maybe others?

content.raw: Number density is not sufficient alone as ``H_number_density`` signifies the number density of neutral atomic hydrogen.
content.html: Number density is not sufficient alone as H_number_density signifies the number density of neutral atomic hydrogen.

content.raw: For clarity, you mean [this section](http://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/YTEPs/YTEP-0003.html#molecular-and-atomic-species-names)?
content.html: For clarity, you mean this section?

content.raw:
Is it generic enough to simply refer to them as 'species' and let the frontends figure out what that means?  So to use `add_species_density_fields` instead of `add_nuclei_density_fields`.

Some frontends (FLASH comes to mind) might have multiple interpretation as they are general enough to use either atomic elements/molecules or nuclei, depending on the simulation.
content.html:
Is it generic enough to simply refer to them as 'species' and let the frontends figure out what that means? So to use add_species_density_fields instead of add_nuclei_density_fields.

Some frontends (FLASH comes to mind) might have multiple interpretation as they are general enough to use either atomic elements/molecules or nuclei, depending on the simulation.

content.raw: Sure, fine, but what should the fields themselves be called?
content.html: Sure, fine, but what should the fields themselves be called?

content.raw: Is there a conflict with what is proposed in the YTEP?  Sorry if I'm missing some connection here...
content.html: Is there a conflict with what is proposed in the YTEP? Sorry if I'm missing some connection here...

content.raw:
As per my comment above, the YTEP dictates that, for example, ``H_number_density`` is the number density of neutral atomic H.  So, in a model where only atomic H species are consider, we have:

``H_number_density`` = n_HI

``H_p1_number_density`` = n_HII

so ``H_nuclei_density`` = n_HI + n_HII

Therefore, it can't simply be ``x_number_density``.
content.html:
As per my comment above, the YTEP dictates that, for example, H_number_density is the number density of neutral atomic H. So, in a model where only atomic H species are consider, we have:

H_number_density = n_HI

H_p1_number_density = n_HII

so H_nuclei_density = n_HI + n_HII

Therefore, it can't simply be x_number_density.

content.raw: I think this is fine, we can do H1_number_density to be protons, H2_number_density for deuterons, and H3_number_density for tritons and be consistent with the YTEP, right?
content.html: I think this is fine, we can do H1_number_density to be protons, H2_number_density for deuterons, and H3_number_density for tritons and be consistent with the YTEP, right?

content.raw: Mike seems to be causing a lot of semantic trouble lately
content.html: Mike seems to be causing a lot of semantic trouble lately

content.raw: ok looking at that section now, perhaps Chris and I should be tasked with doing a nuclear species section ?  (Chris can of course rebuff my volunteering him for this :)
content.html: ok looking at that section now, perhaps Chris and I should be tasked with doing a nuclear species section ? (Chris can of course rebuff my volunteering him for this :)

content.raw: Sounds good to me.  @MatthewTurk, does PyNE do anything funky we should be aware of?
content.html: Sounds good to me. Matt Turk, does PyNE do anything funky we should be aware of?

content.raw: Okay, I see my confusion now.  Sorry for the trouble!
content.html: Okay, I see my confusion now. Sorry for the trouble!

content.raw: I would prefer this as we would then not have to break backward compatibility here.  We have been on the verge of making domain specific distinctions for a while.  We may now be getting to the point where it is necessary.
content.html: I would prefer this as we would then not have to break backward compatibility here. We have been on the verge of making domain specific distinctions for a while. We may now be getting to the point where it is necessary.

content.raw:
They do, but I think it's okay to allow a degree of self-direction for each
domain of science.
content.html: They do, but I think it's okay to allow a degree of self-direction for each domain of science.

content.raw: Although maybe they'd be interested in this discussion? @pshriwise @scopatz.
content.html: Although maybe they'd be interested in this discussion? Patrick Shriwise Anthony Scopatz.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: Gonna bring in @elliottbiondo as well. Any thoughts on this?
content.html: Gonna bring in Elliott Biondo as well. Any thoughts on this?

content.raw: This is a good discussion to have, but let's not lose sight of fixing this bug.  Perhaps the best place is in a yt-dev discussion or a PR to a YTEP.
content.html: This is a good discussion to have, but let's not lose sight of fixing this bug. Perhaps the best place is in a yt-dev discussion or a PR to a YTEP.

description: The nuclei density fields needed to be added to the species field plugin.  This does that and adds a test.
